titleproper.value: Guide to the William Morris Letters <num>TAM 420</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Peter Meyer Filardo

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: William Morris (1834-1896) was a British socialist, poet, artist and architect, and leading figure in the Arts and Crafts movement. Contains signed letters by Morris. Recipients include John Coleman Kenworthy and Theodore Watts-Dunton. Also included is a copy of an 1855 letter from Morris to his mother, Emma Morris.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Materials found in collection; provenance is unknown. The accession number associated with this collection is 1950.232.

<list><item>Derived from: International Institute for Social History Archives http://www.iisg.nl/archives/morris/</item><item>See also: William Morris Society http://www.morrissociety.org/</item><item>See also: William Morris Internet Archive (includes chronology) http://www.marxists.org/archive/morris/</item></list>

The collection contains eleven handwritten letters signed by Morris, a handwritten copy of an 1855 letter from Morris to his mother, Emma Morris, with an accompanying letter of transmittal and envelope. Six letters are to John Coleman Kenworthy, 1863-1948, a younger socialist then living in Liverpool. There are single letters to Charles Augustus Howell (1840-1890); ("I return Rossetti letter...") to poet, author and critic, Theodore Watts-Dunton (re: a manuscript of <title render="italic">The Coming of Love</title>, 1898), and three letters to unidentified recipients. All the items have been encapsulated, except for the copy of the letter to Morris's mother.
